trans-unit.source: Working with the Root Container
trans-unit.target: Working with the Root Container

trans-unit.source: A root container serves as a default container for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: A root container serves as a default container for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: A storage account may have one root container.
trans-unit.target: A storage account may have one root container.

trans-unit.source: The root container must be explicitly created and must be named <codeInline>$root</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: The root container must be explicitly created and must be named <codeInline>$root</codeInline>.

trans-unit.source: A blob stored in the root container may be addressed without referencing the root container name, so that a blob can be addressed at the top level of the storage account hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: A blob stored in the root container may be addressed without referencing the root container name, so that a blob can be addressed at the top level of the storage account hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can now reference a blob that resides in the root container in the following manner:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can now reference a blob that resides in the root container in the following manner:

trans-unit.source: Managing the Root Container
trans-unit.target: Managing the Root Container

trans-unit.source: To use the root container with your storage account, create a new container named <codeInline>$root</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: To use the root container with your storage account, create a new container named <codeInline>$root</codeInline>.

trans-unit.source: The following sample request shows how to create the root container and upload a blob to it:
trans-unit.target: The following sample request shows how to create the root container and upload a blob to it:

trans-unit.source: Like other containers, the root container can be made available for anonymous public access.
trans-unit.target: Like other containers, the root container can be made available for anonymous public access.

trans-unit.source: If the root container is present, it will appear when you list containers in the storage account.
trans-unit.target: If the root container is present, it will appear when you list containers in the storage account.

trans-unit.source: When you list blobs in the root container, the root container does not appear in the resource URLs for the blobs returned.
trans-unit.target: When you list blobs in the root container, the root container does not appear in the resource URLs for the blobs returned.

trans-unit.source: You can also delete the root container if you no longer need it.
trans-unit.target: You can also delete the root container if you no longer need it.

trans-unit.source: A blob in the root container cannot include a forward slash (/) in its name, and be careful to avoid including a trailing forward slash (/) when referencing a blob under the root container.
trans-unit.target: A blob in the root container cannot include a forward slash (/) in its name, and be careful to avoid including a trailing forward slash (/) when referencing a blob under the root container.

trans-unit.source: For example, using this URI results in an error:
trans-unit.target: For example, using this URI results in an error:

trans-unit.source: https://myaccount.blob.core.windows.net/myblob/
trans-unit.target: https://myaccount.blob.core.windows.net/myblob/

trans-unit.source: In the above example, the Blob service reads the container name as myblob and expects to see a blob name after the trailing slash.
trans-unit.target: In the above example, the Blob service reads the container name as myblob and expects to see a blob name after the trailing slash.

trans-unit.source: The request is malformed due to the missing blob name.
trans-unit.target: The request is malformed due to the missing blob name.
